choices.A: Set the parallel_data_backup_backint_channels parameter to a number greater than 1.
choices.C: Delete unnecessary older backup files from backups that SAP Backint agent performed.
choices.E: Reinstall AWS Backint agent by using the AWS Backint installer rather than the Systems Manager document.
choices.B: Select a Provisioned IOPS SSD (io2) volume as the backup target for AWS Backint agent.
choices.D: Change the existing gp2-based SAP HANA data volumes to the Provisioned IOPS SSD (io2) EBS volume type.

questions.question_text:
An SAP database analyst installs AWS Backint Agent for SAP HANA (AWS Backint agent) by using AWS Systems Manager. The SAP database analyst runs an initial test to perform a database backup for a 512 GB SAP HANA database. The database runs on an SAP certified Amazon EC2 instance type with General Purpose SSD (gp2) Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) volumes for all disk storage. The backup is running too slowly.

Which actions should the SAP database analyst take to improve the performance of AWS Backint agent? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
A,D: Increasing the value of the parallel_data_backup_backint_channels parameter allows the Backint agent to execute more than one backup process in parallel, improving the overall backup speed. Switching the EBS volume type from gp2 to io2 provides more consistent and faster I/O performance, which can also speed up backup processes.

Selected Answer: AD
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sap/latest/sap-hana/aws-backint-agent-troubleshooting.html
D: the document says to change the storage type of the whole data filesystem and not just the backup volume

comments.content:
Problem: My backup is running too slowly and is taking a longer time to complete.
Resolution: You can switch your Amazon EBS volumes associated with SAP HANA data filesystem to io1, io2 or gp3 volume type. Additionally, if your database size is greater than 128 GB, you can improve your backup performance by adjusting the number of parallel backup channels. Increase the value of parallel_data_backup_backint_channels and try to initiate your backup again.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A and B because in D I dont understand why just changing the volume type will improve the performance. Potentially it could but B is a clear step to improve. However I go for A and B.

questions.question_text:
A company is planning to retire a data center where a few legacy SAP applications run. The applications are SAP R/3 4.6C with a Microsoft SQL Server 2005 database end are running on Windows Server 2008. The applications are outside the extended maintenance period. There is no SAP support for the applications.

The company has no plans to upgrade the applications or move the applications to a different platform. The company does not have a policy to maintain installation media for any of the applications. The company wants to migrate the applications to AWS.

How can the company migrate the applications to AWS?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A: SAP R/3 4.6C, which is a legacy version, and you don't have installation media, the Launch Wizard may not be the best solution.
B. SAP Software Provisioning Manager (SWPM) is typically used for system copies, but for this to work, you would need the installation media of the application components which you mentioned is not available.
D. Since you don't have installation media, manual installation might be a challenge. Database synchronization is typically not the preferred method for such migrations, as it can be complex, time-consuming, and can lead to data inconsistencies if not done carefully.
So C is correct.

Selected Answer: C
C does makes sense:
https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/awsforsap/automating-sap-migrations-using-cloudendure-migration/
Option E - Terminate the CTO or whoever is making such a poor decision to limp along a system that was built in the early 2000s or earlier.

comments.content:
Manually installing the applications would require access to the installation media, which the company does not have. This option is not feasible without the necessary installation media.

C is correct. Using AWS Application Migration Service to migrate the applications. This service is designed for migrations like this, where the application and database are outdated and unsupported. It allows for the replication of the entire environment, including the older operating system and database, without the need for installation media or specific support for the application version by AWS tools.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D: Given that the SAP applications are legacy versions and out of support, and the company does not have a policy to maintain installation media, the other methods of migration such as using AWS Launch Wizard or Software Provisioning Manager would not be suitable or even possible in this scenario. Therefore, the company will need to manually install the applications on AWS and then perform a database synchronization from the source system to the new target system on AWS.

comments.content: But it is mentioned that there is no SAP support. So I think in this case it wont work.

choices.A: Use AWS Launch Wizard for SAP to launch the applications on AWS. Migrate the applications by using backup and restore.
choices.C: Use AWS Application Migration Service to migrate the applications.
choices.D: Manually install the applications on AWS. Perform a database synchronization from the source to the target.
choices.B: Perform an SAP system copy from the source to the target by using SAP Software Provisioning Manager.

questions.question_text:
A company is running its SAP S/4HANA production system on AWS. The system is 5 TB in size and has a high performance and IOPS demand for the SAP HANA data storage. The company is using Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) General Purpose SSD (gp2) storage with burstable IOPS to meet this demand.

An SAP solutions architect needs to review the current storage layout and recommend a more cost-effective solution without compromising storage performance.

What should the SAP solutions architect recommend to meet these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C: Amazon EBS gp3 volumes offer the ability to independently increase IOPS and throughput without needing to provision additional block storage capacity. This means you can meet the performance requirements of your workloads and scale as needed without over-provisioning and paying for unused resources, making it more cost-effective than gp2. You should replace gp2 with gp3 and configure the required IOPS to meet the high performance and IOPS demand of your SAP HANA system.

C
gp2 →　gp3 is correct.
Baseline is low performance. not D.

choices.C: Replace all the gp2 storage with gp3 storage. Configure the required IOPS.
choices.D: Replace all the gp2 storage with gp3 storage at baseline IOPS.
choices.B: Replace all the gp2 storage with Provisioned IOPS SSD (io2) storage.
choices.A: Switch from burstable IOPS to allocated IOPS for the gp2 storage.

choices.B: No IAM role is attached to the Amazon EC2 instance.
choices.C: AWS Backint agent binaries are owned by a non-root user.
choices.D: AWS Backint agent is connecting to Amazon S3 with VPC endpoints.
choices.A: AWS Systems Manager Agent is not installed on the Amazon EC2 instance.

questions.question_text:
A company uses SAP S/4HANA as its ERP solution. The company is using AWS Backint Agent for SAP HANA (AWS Backint agent) for backups. Although the configuration is correct for AWS Backint agent, the backups are falling with the following error.

NoCredentialProviders: no valid providers in chain.

What could be the reason for this error?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The others here will be right. Its B

Selected Answer: B
B: The error message "NoCredentialProviders: no valid providers in chain" typically means that AWS SDK is unable to find AWS credentials. In this case, the AWS Backint Agent requires an IAM role that allows it to access the S3 bucket where the backups are stored. If this IAM role is not attached to the EC2 instance where the Backint Agent runs, it cannot authenticate to S3 and this error occurs.

Selected Answer: B
I would say it should be B

questions.question_text:
A company needs to migrate its SAP HANA landscape from an on-premises data center to AWS. The company's existing SAP HANA database instance is oversized. The company must resize the database instance as part of the migration.

Which combination of steps should the company take to ensure that the target Amazon EC2 instance is sized optimally for the SAP HANA database instance? (Choose two.)

choices.E: For the target system, select any current-generation EC2 memory optimized instance.
choices.A: Determine the peak memory utilization of the existing on-premises SAP HANA system.
choices.B: Determine the average memory utilization of the existing on-premises SAP HANA system.
choices.D: For the target system, select the smallest SAP certified EC2 instance that provides more memory than the current peak memory utilization.
choices.C: For the target system, select any SAP certified EC2 instance that provides more memory than the current average memory utilization.

discussion.content: A,D: When sizing an SAP HANA instance, it's crucial to take into account the peak memory utilization. Choosing an instance size that is based on the average memory utilization may result in performance issues during periods of peak demand. Therefore, it's important to choose an instance that can handle the highest memory demand anticipated. It's also more cost-effective to choose the smallest instance that meets these requirements.

Selected Answer: D
A, D for sure. Peak memory utilization should be considered while provisioning target instance for HANA.

Selected Answer: A
Its A&D here

exam.name: AWS Certified SAP on AWS - Specialty PAS-C01
